Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the father should provide guidance
Situation2: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, blueprints spread out before me, laptop open to the project management dashboard. My son, Ethan, shuffled in, dragging his feet, mumbling a half-hearted “good morning.” I caught the eye roll when I reminded him to greet everyone properly. As a father, I knew I should pause, sit with him, and talk about respect and kindness—reinforce the values I want him to carry. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: the client was expecting an update on the new library’s progress. As the architect, I needed to check the contractors’ reports, make sure the timeline wasn’t slipping. My mind tugged in two directions—one voice urging me to close the laptop and focus on Ethan, the other insisting I couldn’t let the project drift. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
